review.title: Why Bother With Syntax?
review.abstract: This short note discusses the role of syntax vs. semantics and the interplay between logic, philosophy, and language in computer science and game theory.

Halpern, Cornell University Computer Science DepartmentIthaca, NY 14853 halpern @ cs.cornell.eduhttp: / / www.cs.cornell.edu / home / halpernJune 18, 2015Rohit and I go a long way back. We started talking about Dynamic Logic when I was a doctoral student, when we met at seminars at MIT (my consultant Albert Meyer was at MIT even though I was at Harvard, and Rohit was at Boston University at the time). I appreciated Rohit's breadth, his quick insights, his intellect, and his inviting and endearing style. Rohit has been interested in the interplay of logic, philosophy, and language since I've known him. Over the years, we've both been interested in game theory. I'd like to devote this short section to discussing all these issues.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: When economists know this, they usually do it on a semantic (or secondary) level. Events correspond to the settlements and the settlements of the settlements. On the other hand, in the literature about thinking in philosophy and in logic, there is an additional layer that is supported by the settlements of the settlements.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: The point of this brief remark should be obvious: there are times when the syntax is useful, despite its overhead. Moreover, game theorists like Molie Yres "M. Jourdain, who discovers that he has spoken prose all his life [Molie Yre 2013], have often used syntax without recognizing it (or at least without explicitly acknowledging its use), but they have not always used it to its full extent. That is, as I have shown in [Halpern 1999], there are times when semantics is useful, and the overhead of the syntax is not worth it. Semantic proofs of validity are typically much easier to perform than their syntactic counterparts (as anyone who has tried to prove the validity of even a simple formula like K).
